trans-unit.source: This topic describes the functionality available from the Microsoft Dynamics AX Intelligent Data Management Framework (IDMF) Analysis menu.
Analysis in the Intelligent Data Management Framework (AX 2012)
This topic describes the functionality available from the Microsoft Dynamics AX Intelligent Data Management Framework (IDMF) Analysis menu.
The **Analysis** menu lets you analyze the production and archive databases, and application health statistics, from the production replica database.
IDMF automatically starts in the **Analysis dashboard** view for the production database.
The **Analysis dashboard** command shows a graphical view of the database that resembles the following screen shot.
At least two database analysis schedules must be completed before the database growth trend chart is displayed.
The controls and commands available for the analysis dashboard are similar for the production database and the archive database.
The command you click becomes unavailable, to visually distinguish the database that is being used.
For example, when you click **Analysis dashboard** from the **Production database** group, the command becomes unavailable, as shown in the following screen shot.
Navigation of the Analysis dashboard workspace
The following table describes the panes in the Analysis dashboard workspace.
Provides a graphical view of the top 10 tables by row count.
The pie chart shows the name of the table and the number of rows when you point to an area.
The percentage shown for each table is calculated from the number of rows in the table versus the total rows in the top 10 tables.
Provides a graphical view of the top 10 tables by data size.
The pie chart shows the name and size of the table when you point to an area.
The percentage shown for each table is calculated from the size of the table versus the total size of the top 10 tables.
Provides a graphical view of the top 10 tables by index size.
The pie chart shows the name of the table and the size of the index when you point to an area.
The percentage shown for each table is calculated from the index size of the table versus the total index size of the top 10 tables.
One chart provides a graphical view of the table space used by the top 10 tables versus other tables.
The other chart provides a graphical view of the index space used by the top 10 tables versus other tables.
Provides a trend analysis of your production or archive database over multiple snapshots.
You must have a minimum of two snapshots to see the trend analysis.
The trend analysis processes the 10 most recent snapshots.
Snapshots that are older than the 10 most recent snapshots are ignored by the trend analysis feature.
Provides the row count trend analysis of your production or archive database over multiple snapshots.
You must have a minimum of two snapshots to see the trend analysis.
The trend analysis processes the 10 most recent snapshots.
Snapshots that are older than the 10 most recent snapshots are ignored by the trend analysis feature.
The **Analysis details** command provides detailed database analysis information that resembles the following screen shot.
At least two database analysis schedules must be completed before the table growth trend chart and the **Growth trend** button are displayed.

Use the Analysis details workspace to work with database and index analysis for the production or archive database, to work with the performance dashboard for the selected database, or to manage indexes for the production database.
The controls and commands available for the analysis details are similar for the production database and the archive database.
The command you click becomes unavailable, to visually distinguish the database that is being used.
For example, when you click **Analysis details** from the **Production database** group, the command becomes unavailable, as shown in the following screen shot.
Navigation of the Analysis details workspace
The following tables provide descriptions for the controls in this workspace.
For a detailed explanation of Microsoft SQL Server terms, see the [SQL Server documentation](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=227464).
Displays sizing statistics for each table.
By default, IDMF displays the top 50 tables.
You can select **Top 100 tables** or **All tables** by using the filter on the title bar of the pane.
Displays index statistics for the selected table and lets you defragment selected fragmented indexes.
Provides additional information about some tables.
If the selected table has any additional information, it appears in this pane.
Read the related information carefully, because it provides critical insights about the selected table.
Appears below the Related information pane, and displays the Table information view by default.
Change the graphical view by clicking a button that appears below the Graphical view pane.
Provides information about the data size and index size, and index information for indexes of the selected table.
Provides information about the index statistics, such as the index reads, index writes, and system fragmentation percentage.
Select one or more rows in the grid, and then click **Defragment index** to create a schedule to defragment the selected indexes.
Creating and managing schedules is covered later in this topic.
Create a schedule to defragment selected indexes.
Display a graphical view of the growth trend of the selected table.
This button appears only after successful completion of two or more database analysis snapshot schedules.
Display a graphical view of the record count by company for the selected table.
Display a graphical view of the top 10 tables by data size, in megabytes.
Display a graphical view of the top 10 unused indexes by index size.
Display a graphical view of the top 10 fragmented indexes.
Display a graphical view of data size by table group.
Display a graphical view of data size by configuration key.
Additional details for the selected alert, if there are any, appear in the Related information pane.
The number of rows in the table.
The size that is reserved for the table in the database, in megabytes.
The total data size of the table, in megabytes.
The total index size for the table, in megabytes.
The unused database space in this table, in megabytes.
The index-to-data ratio for this table, expressed as a percentage.
Fields (Index details pane, Index details tab)
The columns that are used to create the index.
Index properties, such as clustered, non-clustered, unique, or primary key.
Fields (Index details pane, Index stats tab)
By default, the data grid displays an average of all snapshots which is indicated by the value **All** in the **Stats time** column.
Expand each index to see the statistics for each snapshot.
Expand this node to see statistics for each snapshot.
The timestamp for each snapshot, or an average of all snapshots (shown as **All**).
By default, the data grid is set to **All**.
Index properties, such as clustered, non-clustered, unique, or primary key.
The fields that are used to create the index.
The average fragmentation percentage for the index across all database snapshots.
Select one or more indexes, and then click **Defragment index** to create a schedule to defragment the selected indexes.
This command lets you create a schedule to defragment fragmented indexes.
Follow these steps to create a schedule to defragment fragmented indexes:
Click **Analysis** > **Manage indexes** to open the **Manage indexes** window.
This window contains the **Unused indexes** and **Fragmented indexes** tabs.
Both tabs provide a data grid that contains **Table name** and **Index name** fields.
The **Fragmented indexes** tab also provides fragmentation percentages for indexes.
Use this window to create a schedule to defragment fragmented indexes.
In the **Manage indexes** window, click the **Fragmented indexes** tab.
This tab provides a list of all the tables and their fragmented indexes.
Use the **Advanced** filter control to search by table name or fragmentation percentage.
Click the column headings in the data grid to sort the column in ascending or descending sequence.
Select the table or index of interest.
You can select multiple indexes from multiple tables.
You must select at least one index to create a schedule.
In the **Task details** pane, enter the required information, and then click **Save**.
Confirm that the schedule appears in the **Scheduled tasks** pane.
Some indexes retain a non-zero fragmentation percentage even after the defragmentation schedule is completed successfully.
This command provides similar information for the archive database as the **Analysis dashboard** command in the **Production database** group provides for the production database.
This command provides similar information for the archive database as the Analysis details command in the Production database group provides for the production database.
For detailed information, see [Analysis functionality in the Microsoft Dynamics AX Intelligent Data Management Framework workspace (IDMF)](analysis-functionality-idmf-workspace.md).
This command provides graphical views and details for key measures from the Microsoft Dynamics AX application, based on predetermined queries.
You can also create your own queries by using the **Administer** > **Application health check** command.
A measure captures aggregated statistics for key business processes for each company in the Microsoft Dynamics AX application.
This information is captured across calendar years, based on the ledger periods you set up in the application.
For example, the measure **Number of inactive Sales Quotations** is calculated as "the total number of sales quotations which are canceled, confirmed, or lost."
The total is grouped by company and by year.

The application health check provides key measures for the **Inventory**, **Accounts receivable**, **Accounts payable**, **General ledger**, and **Administration** modules, as shown in the following screen shot.
Navigation of the Application health check workspace
The following tables provide descriptions for the controls in this workspace.
Provides aggregates of measures by company and by year for selected modules from the Microsoft Dynamics AX application.
The default view is the aggregate of all companies by year.
Expand the measure to select the measure statistics for individual companies.
Provides additional information for the selected measure, including a brief description, the archival relevance, and the formula that was used to calculate the measure.
Shows a graphical view of the selected measure for the first company in the data grid.
If there are multiple companies, expand the measure and select another company to change the graphical view.
When you point to an area, the chart shows the year and value for the selected measure.
Shows a graphical view of the aggregate value for all companies for the selected measure, by year.
The chart shows the year and value for the selected measure when you point to an area.
Shows the aggregate trend analysis from different snapshots.
You must complete at least two health check analysis schedules to see a graphical view in this pane.
The trend analysis captures the 10 most recent snapshots and ignores older snapshots, if there are any.
Provides selected measures from the **Inventory management** module.
Provides selected measures from the **Accounts receivable** module.
Provides selected measures from the **Accounts payable** module.
Provides selected measures from the **General ledger** module.
Provides selected measures from the **Administration** module.
Company accounts in Microsoft Dynamics AX represent the organizational structure of a company.
An aggregate of the measure for all the companies by year is listed as All.
The aggregate of the measure is put in a column for each year, based on the ledger period configuration.
This command provides information about SQL Server configuration options, database options, and statistics for tables and indexes for the production and archive databases.
This command displays the database configuration details for all databases used by IDMF, and table statistics and query statistics for the production and archive databases.
Navigation of the Performance dashboard workspace
The following tables provide descriptions for the controls in this workspace.

Provides information about the database properties and configuration options for the selected database, such as information about the data and log files, database options, and other database properties.
This information is available for the selected database.
This tab is only available when you select the production or archive database from the list on the **Database configuration** tab.

Provides information about table statistics for the selected database, such as tables without clustered indexes, tables with missing indexes, tables with locks, and tables that can be enabled for caching in Application Object Server (AOS).
This tab is only available when you select the production or archive database from the list on the **Database configuration** tab.
Provides information about the query statistics, such as the cached query plans, query statement, and query plan for the selected cached query plan.

Provides database properties for the selected database, such as the database name, database owner, and number of active users, information about database and log files, and the currently configured values for the database options.
Provides the minimum, maximum, configured, and currently used (run) values of advanced configuration options for SQL Server.
You can enable these tables so that Application Object Server (AOS) caches the whole table.
To enable a table for caching, change the **CacheLookup** property of the table to **EntireTable**.
For more information, see the Microsoft Dynamics AX developer documentation in the [MSDN Library](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/cc678142.aspx).
Provides a list of tables without a clustered index.
Provides a list of tables that do not have any index.
Provides a list of locked tables together with relevant details, such as the row or page lock count, and the row or page lock wait time.
Provides statistics for the cached query plans, such as the usage count, and logical and physical reads and writes.
Provides the Transact-SQL query statement that was used to create the cached query plan.
Click **Export** to export the query text as an SQL text file.
Provides the query plan for the query text that was used to create the selected cached query plan.
Click **Export** to export the query plan as an XML file.
Select a database from the list.
The performance dashboard displays relevant information for the selected database.
The name of the database property, such as database name, owner, status, creation date, collation, last backup date, or number of users.
The value of the database property.
For example, the owner property value displays the current owner of the database.
The name of the data or log file.
The file name of the data or log file.
The name of the file group that is used for the data file.
The size of the data or log file, in kilobytes (KB).
The growth size for the data or log file, in kilobytes (KB) or as a percentage.
Whether the file is used for the data or transaction log.
The name of the database option, such as database name, compatibility level, recovery model, or auto close.
The value of the database option.
The name of the SQL Server configuration option.
The minimum value of the configuration option.
The maximum value of the configuration option.
The value to which the configuration option was set by using sp\_configure (the value in sys.configurations.value).

For more information about these options, see [Setting Server Configuration Options](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms189631.aspx) and [sys.configurations (Transact-SQL)](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms188345.aspx).

The currently running value of the configuration option (the value in sys.configurations.value\_in\_use).For more information, see [sys.configurations (Transact-SQL)](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms188345.aspx).
Fields (Table stats tab, Cacheable tables list)
The number of rows in the table.
Fields (Table stats tab, Tables without clustered index list)
The number of rows in the table.
The number of times this index was used for read operations.
Fields (Table stats tab, Missing indexes list)
A comma-separated list of columns that contribute to equality predicates, in the form table.column = constant\_value.
A comma-separated list of columns that contribute to inequality predicates, such predicates in the form table.column > constant\_value.
A comma-separated list of columns required as covering columns for the query.
The average cost of the user queries that may be able to be reduced by the index in the group.
The average benefit, as a percentage, that user queries may be able to experience if this missing index group is implemented.
The value means that the query cost may, on average, drop by this percentage if this missing index group is implemented.
The date and time of the last seek caused by user queries that the recommended index in the group could have been used for.
The number of compilations and recompilations that may benefit from this missing index group.
Compilations and recompilations of many different queries can contribute to this column value.
Index properties, such as clustered, non-clustered, unique, primary key, or heap.
The total number of milliseconds the database engine waited on a row lock.
The total number of milliseconds the database engine waited on a page lock.
The cumulative number of times (milliseconds) the database engine waited on a row lock.
The cumulative number of row locks requested.
The cumulative number of page locks requested.
The cumulative number of times (milliseconds) the database engine waited on a page lock.
The cumulative number of times the database engine escalated locks.
The **Select a snapshot** **time** list lets you select query plan statistics, query text, and a query plan for a specific analysis snapshot.
By default, the list displays the most recent time.
The data grid filters the information based on your selection.
The following table describes the fields in the data grid.
The number of time the plan has been run since it was last compiled.
The total elapsed time, in microseconds, for completed processing of this plan.
The total amount of CPU time, in microseconds, that was consumed by processing of this plan since it was compiled.
The average amount of CPU time, in microseconds, based on the **Usage count** and **Total worker time** values.
The average number of physical reads performed by processing of this plan since it was compiled.
The average number of logical reads performed by processing of this plan since it was compiled.
The elapsed time, in microseconds, for the most recently completed processing of this plan**.**
The minimum elapsed time, in microseconds, for any completed processing of this plan.
The maximum elapsed time, in microseconds, for any completed processing of this plan.
The total number of physical reads performed by processing of this plan since it was compiled.
The number of physical reads performed the last time the plan was processed.
The minimum number of physical reads that this plan has ever performed during a single processing.
The maximum number of physical reads that this plan has ever performed during a single processing.
The total number of logical reads performed by processing of this plan since it was compiled.
The number of logical reads performed the last time the plan was processed.
The minimum number of logical reads that this plan has ever performed during a single processing.
The maximum number of logical reads that this plan has ever performed during a single processing.
The total number of logical writes performed by processing of this plan since it was compiled.
The number of logical writes performed the last time the plan was processed.
The minimum number of logical writes that this plan has ever performed during a single processing.
The maximum number of logical writes that this plan has ever performed during a single processing.
The CPU time, in microseconds, that was consumed the last time the plan was processed.
The minimum CPU time, in microseconds, that this plan has ever consumed during a single processing.
The maximum CPU time, in microseconds, that this plan has ever consumed during a single processing.
This command lets you export selected rows from the data grid in all workspaces where this command is available.
